Activity: Build a personal AI learning roadmap with goals, tools to try, methods to track success, and reflection checkpoints.
Create a “creator’s logbook” documenting your ideation, AI tool choices, iterations, and emotional response to AI’s involvement.
Compile a reflective portfolio that includes AI-assisted writing, self-analysis of process, and ethical stance on using AI in scholarly work.
Students build a functioning low-code AI prototype using tools like Peltarion, Zapier, or Scratch + Teachable Machine.
Plan and create a multimedia project (e.g., music video or animation) using at least three AI tools in the workflow.
Develop a digital exhibit (e.g., timeline, archive, or podcast) using AI to help structure and format content.
Design a simple concept for an AI system that addresses a specific campus or social need (e.g., sustainability dashboard).
Create a mixed-media AI-assisted artwork exploring the concept of “creativity vs. automation.”
Students collaborate to write a speculative fiction short story about the future of AI ethics, guided by real theories.
Build a slide deck or infographic explaining how an AI system like ChatGPT works, using both AI and peer-reviewed info.
Curate a mini-gallery of AI-generated artworks, with accurate fact-based labels explaining medium, process, and input used.
Construct a timeline or zine using AI to visualize factual developments in AI’s role in society.
Students complete an AI learning journal that includes entries reflecting on tool use, decision-making strategies, and peer feedback.
Hold peer-review sessions where students give feedback on each other’s creative AI process logs and personal toolkits.
Students create self-assessments reflecting on their AI-assisted research habits and evaluate changes they’d make.
Analyze the differences in process and output when using two different prompt strategies for the same coding task in the same AI tool.
Evaluate how well a text-to-image AI tool followed a detailed script or storyboard, and suggest workflow improvements.
Compare and critique the output from two AI writing assistants given the same research topic, using a rubric.
Debate whether deep learning should be used in high-stakes fields like medicine, using AI-generated arguments for and against.
Students critique AI-generated works based on aesthetic theory (e.g., formalism vs. expressionism) in a group critique format.
Assess the fairness of AI moderation algorithms using real-world case studies (e.g., social media flagging or deletion of posts), applying conceptual ethics frameworks.
Students critique the accuracy of an AI-generated explanation of a scientific process by cross-referencing with textbooks and databases.
Use an AI-generated summary of an artist’s work and identify factual inconsistencies about techniques, historical periods, or named artists.
Compare AI-written historical summaries with verified sources to flag misleading or omitted facts.
Students keep a debugging log with AI assistant support and reflect on decision points.
Analyze own AI usage patterns across tools (text, image, audio) and explain when and why they shift strategy.
Use a decision tree to analyze how personal bias might influence acceptance of AI claims in different contexts.
Students experiment with prompt engineering to improve model output and document what worked best.
Modify input parameters for a text-to-image generator and analyze how the visual output changes.
Dissect AI-supported annotation tools and compare how they affect the interpretation of historical documents.
Compare model structures (decision tree vs. neural net) by visualizing workflows and dissecting their logic.
Deconstruct how different AI models interpret a prompt like "peace" or "chaos" and analyze outcomes.
Break down AI-generated persuasive texts to determine the rhetorical strategy used.
Given AI-generated data outputs, students identify incorrect or hallucinated data and mark discrepancies.
Analyze metadata from an AI-generated image and annotate potential ethical red flags (e.g., training data issues).
Use multiple AI summarizers on the same article and critique which tool captures nuance best.
Students create a personalized "AI Toolbox" listing tools best suited to their learning or research style and explain their rationale.
Use two different AI tools with the same prompt for a creative output in your chosen modality and document your experience, thought processes, and preferences during each stage of AI output.
Students journal how their critical thinking shifts when using AI for brainstorming vs. outlining.
Build a basic predictive model using Google AutoML or a no-code AI tool and test it with a small data set.
Follow instructor-provided guides to generate voiceovers for animations using AI, then test for clarity and tone.
Use a transcription AI tool (like Otter.ai) to convert and organize interview audio, then compare it with a human-transcribed version.
Given different types of AI algorithms, students match them with appropriate real-world problems and justify their choices.
Students create a collage using AI tools, basing it on a conceptual theme (e.g., “decay” or “nostalgia”).
Students create AI-generated personas for a dialogue about social justice, then reflect on the alignment of personas with known ethical theories.
Students identify AI tools suited for specific data sets and justify their tool choice by referencing AI technical documentation.
Use AI-generated filters in Adobe tools to re-edit an old design or image, documenting what was changed and why.
Students use AI to summarize articles and apply those summaries in discussion board debates.
After using different AI tools, students reflect on when they felt most in control and least in control, and chart their confidence over time.
Students track the types of prompts they tend to use across tools and reflect on how that shapes their outcomes.
Students predict how their own values affect how they interpret AI-generated historical narratives, then compare predictions to actual reactions.
Students analyze steps taken by an AI assistant to solve a math or data science problem, then narrate those steps as a screencast.

Use AI to generate a piece of music or art, then write a reflection on the steps taken throughout the process: what prompts, edits, or instructions were given to the AI tool to create the final output?
Break down how a chatbot constructs a dialogue using temperature, tone, and persona settings—then teach it to a peer.
Given several AI outputs, students work in pairs to group them based on the type of learning used (e.g., classification vs. clustering).
Compare how three different AI tools interpret the same visual prompt, then chart the style differences and speculate why.
Students use AI to search for examples of AI metaphors in fiction or nonfiction, then present how each example frames AI conceptually.
Students annotate a diagram of a machine learning workflow generated by an AI diagramming tool (like diagrams.net + ChatGPT).
Watch a video created by an AI video generator, then write a short explanation of how the AI created visual transitions or effects.
Use ChatGPT to ask questions about how it selects sources or builds answers, then write a paragraph explaining its logic.
Students complete a guided reflection form on past AI tools they’ve used, what worked well, what confused them, and what they want to improve.
Students fill in a digital journal after exploring 3 AI tools for creativity (e.g., Midjourney, ChatGPT, Lumen5), noting personal ease/difficulty.
Students reflect on how their research habits have changed after using AI tools, using a Google Doc worksheet shared for peer feedback.
Students record a screen-capture tutorial using AI assistants (like GitHub Copilot or Scribehow) to demonstrate the steps of a workflow relating to their course or intended career field.
Students complete a step-by-step walkthrough of uploading audio into an AI music tool (like Amper Music), then explain each step to a partner.
In a scavenger hunt, students identify procedures for detecting AI-generated content in academic writing using tools like Turnitin or ZeroGPT.
In small groups, students use ChatGPT to look up and compile definitions for types of machine learning (supervised, unsupervised, reinforcement) and create a mini-poster.
Students create a mind map in Canva with AI tool integrations, classifying AI tools into categories like generative, assistive, or curatorial.
Students use an AI chatbot to summarize and categorize different ethical theories used in AI ethics debates, then quiz each other.
Use an AI art platform and list all features available in the tool; then match them to their creative applications in a worksheet.
In a timeline-building activity, students label key developments in AI history
